subject: chassis: Set Chassis.Reset to support only RackMount and StandAlone type

User approved, CI ok to start

Build Successful 

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/23236/ : SUCCESS

Patch Set 2:

I am wondering why we add this Chassis reset for all Chassis resource. Should all the chassis chassis resources be linked to reset function for the whole chassis system?

This is probably not the right way to do this... I am not sure if we want to have Chassis reset when the Chassis is created based off Item.Board.
Uploaded patch set 3.

Patch Set 3: Ok-To-Test+1

User approved, CI ok to start

Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> I am wondering why we add this Chassis reset for all Chassis resource. Should all the chassis chassis resources be linked to reset function for the whole chassis system?
> 
> This is probably not the right way to do this... I am not sure if we want to have Chassis reset when the Chassis is created based off Item.Board.

moved it to under the main chassis only for now. Maybe that is more reasonable?

Patch Set 47:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 47:

(1 comment)

I don't think this makes sense. 
I don't think the "MainChassis" should be the first one. 
Can we look for Chassis of a certain type? E.g. RackMount 
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/Chassis.interface.yaml#L12

oh yes, that makes a lot more sense.

I also need to add Chassid Type support for this first. Since it hardcore to RackMount right now.

oh also, I guess the implementation in https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/redfish_util.hpp#L51 is wrong then?

It uses the first one to act as the main chassis.

Ug... yeah.  I think that code was right at one point in time (when i think we were only searching for Item.Chassis), but looking at it, it looks wrong.  I wonder how many systems that's broken on.  Right now it only drives the chassis links which aren't used that often, so it's not that surprising nobody noticed.

Please talk a little more about what the expected user change will be.  Presumably the Chassis.Reset actions are going to disappear on anything except for the main chassis.  This has some client impact that we should discuss in the commit message.

With that said, considering that this could've never given the appropriate response (ie resetting a single component) I can't imagine anyone was relying on that behavior, although lets sort through that.
I have added more detail on how this change will affect existing systems and what are the expectation of this change.
This patchset also changes the behavior such that Chassis are no longer hardcoded to RackMount.  This is probably fine, but definitely needs accounted for in your commit message.

The type will still be defaulted to RackMount on resources that did not specifically update the Type.

`Unknown` is the default for the interface and will also default to `RackMount` in the output.
Ack
You seem to be overriding this parameter down below, but you didn't remove it from the initial fill in.
yeah, I did it on purpose to have the default behavior list this and erase it. But I will do it the other way to follow how it is done generally.
move will be good here. callback{std::move{callback}}

Done.


Thanks.

```
std::move of the const variable 'callback' has no effect; remove std::move() or make the variable non-const [performance-move-const-arg,-warnings-as-errors]
```

I guess we don't need it.
Please avoid this pattern of filling in the json, then erasing it later.  It's difficult to track as a reader.  Generally we would defer filling in the property until we knew that it was ok to do so.
done. I have flipped the logic to add the ActionInfo if it is RackMount or no property found. The default Type is RackMount
Can't this whole method be replaced with "getChassisType" and moving line 753 into the handler?

getChassisType has the assumption that we already found the chassis object path.

This function just help find the Chassis and just call getChassisType once it find the Chassis in question.
As a general rule, objects that call callbacks should ALWAYS call the callback, forwarding a return code when needed.

something like this?

```
std::get_if<std::string>(&property);
```

should fail and call the default callback("") instead of passing a valid argument into it.

yep.  although generally callback would accept an error code type, so you'd forward on the ec in case there was more specific handling needed

something like callback(ec, "")
Done
This isn't something we generally check.  value != "xyz..." effectively is already checking for not empty.

Checking value != "xyz..." does not guarantee that it is not empty.

In this case, I wanted to make sure that use the default value if it is empty or it is equal to Unknown.

But since it should never be empty. I guess its fine not to check it.
generally if it's empty, that case gets covered when you convert to a Redfish enum, because empty string won't match any redfish type.
if unknown is a legal value, we shouldn't be filtering it here, we should be filtering it when we do the conversion to Redfish Enum.
Done. I have handled it in the callback
`size_t`?

I think I like auto a bit too much 😊.

thanks.
Auto is great..... for code writers.  We optimize for readers in this codebase.
Ack
consider `index + 1 != size()`? size_t is unsigned integer so it might underflow (though the previous condition seems to have avoided it)

I am fine either way, I will just change it.

Thanks.
first off, you should just call the callback and return here, no need to process further if you've found the entry.  Also, this should be returning the openbmc value.

I have cleaned it up a bit.

-----

not sure what you meant by the openbmc value?

doing rfind(".") then substr just gives you everything past the .

technically dbus could reply with xyz.openbmc_project.Item.Foobar, and you would then forward Foobar to Redfish, which is illegal.  One could argue that the dbus contract got broken there, but in practice, people break the dbus apis a lot, and new enums get added.  Not doing substr lets us gracefully handle new enums.
Done
seems redundant?
this was there before. I didn't want to change anything on those codes. Just factoring it there.

Yeah, this is an old pattern we used to have because we didn't understand the reference to value promotion rules on lambdas.  Because we're changing this code around, lets just fix it while we're here.
Done

I am not sure which is better.

if else? or individual if statements. Since no two statements will be true at the same time.

I think if else might be a bit slower due to the processor having to backtrack if it takes the wrong path. Not sure if it matters at all here or if there are any preference on this.
Ack
Call callback with error?
Done

like I mentioned in the other comment, don't do it this way, write a method with exact string matches.  Otherwise if a daemon sends us

Foo.Bar.Baz, we end up sending out Baz, which is a redfish spec violation.

Done.

I have listed the different ChassisType supported.

chassisType.empty() is being overloaded two mean:

1. the dbus call failed.
AND 
2. we couldn't find the chassis type.

You likely need to pass through an error code in here.

I was thinking that eitherway it will have the same result. Default to `RackMount`.


Or do we watnt to log it to make it easier to tell what failed/caused the output?
Done
Lets break this out to a method.  We're too many scopes deep here.
Done
ActionNotSupported ?
Done

should this be a ActionNotSupported or something else ? Resource not found?
https://redfish.dmtf.org/registries/Base.1.10.0.json
Done
Why not StandAlone also?

no particular reason.

I'll also add it.
Done

There are some error here that we found in our testing system.

Adding this to block this while fixing it.

Basically, this fail all Chassis Resources that does not have `Item.Chassis` interface.
Done
Why was this changed to ERROR trace? General rule I've been pushing for is if we're not returning an error to the client, lets not trace to the ERROR buffer. This may just be a rebase issue.

oh. I thought I changed it on accident after rebase and changed it manually. Apparently it was good before.

I have reverted it.
If we go with the default "RackMount" then don't we need to add the Actions?

this is actually wrong. I was debugging it and it should be also add the action.

It is indicated by chassisType == nullopt

This one check if chassisType == nullopt or if is equals to RackMount/StandAlone, then it will add the Action. Otherwise, no action.

So the default RckMount will also add the Action.
Done
ERROR? This will trigger an error response to the client so be good to have this log when error traces are enabled.
Done
Is all this code really needed? The code above ensures we don't return this action unless it's supported. If we do need a check, can't we just reuse the logic above vs. writing all this new code?

Do you mean the one in `requestRoutesChassis()`?

This function is used in requestRoutesChassisResetActionInfo and requestRoutesChassisResetAction. I'll see if I can clean this up more.
Done
nit: this should be "addChassisReset"
Done
This doesn't seem right.  Shouldn't we be checking for which chassis dbus interfaces actually implement reset?
Right now it is assuming that RackMount and StandAlone does reset. Also default which is Rackmount.

the only chassis reset that we do is with `xyz.openbmc_project.State.Chassis` and
`/xyz/openbmc_project/state/chassis_system0` or `/xyz/openbmc_project/state/chassis0`.

SO right now it is just saying that which Chassis is allowed to call that method. The Chassis resource itself does not link to the that dbus interface directly (or maybe it should).

Basically, there are no reset method per Chassis and I am not sure if that's an issue.

This Api seems inconvenient. Let's say I want to check if my cassis support rest instead of true/false I get "RackMount", "StandAlone" or nullopt and all of them means true.

Why not just use std::function<boost::system::error_code ec, bool> as a callback type?
I have updated it so that it still support other chassis and just return empty reset list.

This general pattern of "check interfaces, then call set" is generally not how we do things like this.  Generally we take a pattern of attempting to do the set directly, and returning the correct errors.  I think some of the conflict is that you're making a distinction based on type in bmcweb code, which is kind of business logic.  bmcweb should be as close to a dumb dbus->redfish converter as is possible, so we should be relying on whether or not the objects implement the interfaces we need.
ok, let me clean this up a bit more.
I have removed anything unnecessary and use the error to catch everything else.
Why is this comment useful?
Krzysztof, it would help a lot to prefix these types of comments with "nit" because removing this would definitely not hold up this patchset.
Ok, I will keep it in mind.
Done
Please don't make copies of crow::request.  They are generally not needed.
Done
This comment doesn't seem accurate.
Done. Thanks.
Willy, can you please go through all the unresolved comments and mark them as resolved.  I believe there are still some unresolved.

If ec is being handled here, does ec need to be given to the lambda at all?

Could we do a simple:

 crow::connections::systemBus->async_method_call(
        std::bind_front(callback, asyncResp, chassisId),
        connectionName, path, "org.freedesktop.DBus.Properties", "Get",
        "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Chassis", "Type");



(yes, this is using bind_front, which I'm pretty sure I"m going to start transitioning to.  Please help to review https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/51655)

um. Yeah, I think we can do that and just handle it at the callback side.

Thanks for the reference. Let me take a look at the change.

I have cleaned it up a bit based on that.
Please do this directly in the callback.  The less information we have in the lambda, the better.
done.
Pretty sure you meant to return from this?
yes, thanks.
variable needs a better name, this is "add chassis reset action", and should have a name to match.
Done

This didn't work.

I think it need to be res.jsonValue["Parameters"][0]["AllowableValues"]
Have you thought about if ... else if ...else if ladder here .?
this is not needed since it will return if it goes inside the function.
